'''Megan Mullins''' (born November 24, 1987)<ref name="allmusic" /> is an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist. At age 18, she made her debut on the country music scene with the single "Ain't What It Used to Be," a Top 40 hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. Her debut album was originally slated for release in 2006 but was never released.<ref name="fort">{{cite news|url=http://www.journalgazette.net/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071005/ENT02/710050387 |title=Singing a Broken record |accessdate=December 13, 2007 |last=Penhollow |first=Steve |date=October 5, 2007 |newspaper=[[Fort Wayne Journal-Gazette]]}}</ref>

==Biography==
Mullins was born in [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]].<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/megan-mullins-mn0001521468 | title=Megan Mullins Songs, Albums, Reviews, Bio & More | website=[[AllMusic]] }}</ref> She began to learn several instruments at an early age, and by age 3, she had won the Indiana State Fair Showmanship award at the State Fiddle Championship.<ref name="allmusic"/> Many of her family members are also professional musicians, most notably her brother Marcus, with whom she performed on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] at age 14.<ref name="allmusic"/>

By 2006, she was signed to [[Broken Bow Records]], an independent record label. Her first single, titled "Ain't What It Used to Be" (also recorded by [[Billy Currington]] on his debut album) was issued early that year, reaching a peak of No. 32 on the country music charts. A second single, "Cryin' Days," failed to chart at all, and Mullins announced in October 2007 that she would be returning to the studio for further work on the album.<ref name="fort"/>

Although the album has not been released, Mullins remained on Broken Bow's roster. In 2008, Mullins recorded a duet with former [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]] lead singer [[Randy Owen]] (who is also signed to Broken Bow), for his solo debut album ''[[One on One (Randy Owen album)|One on One]]''. Mullins also plays fiddle in Owen's road band.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/concertreview.asp?xid=327 |title=Randy Owen leaves Alabama behind |accessdate=December 2, 2008 |last=Remz |first=Jeffrey B. |date=August 3, 2008|work=[[Country Standard Time]]}}</ref> In April 2009, she switched to Stoney Creek, a sister label also started by the founder of Broken Bow. Her first release for Stoney Creek, "Long Past Gone", made its chart debut in May 2009, and peaked at No. 48 later in the year. A second single for the label, "Tradin' My Halo for Horns," failed to chart. In August 2010, Mullins and Stoney Creek parted ways.
